Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing a message from Alex: “Can we talk? Had a rough day.” My heart sinks. I know he’s been anxious about his project, and now he needs me. I want to be there, to listen, to reassure him that he’s more than his boss’s opinion. But my laptop screen is filled with red flags—performance warnings in the code review. The new feature is so close to being done, but if I don’t fix these issues tonight, the team will be blocked tomorrow. My lead expects clean, efficient code, and I can’t let them down. I stare at the blinking cursor, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. I want to close my laptop and call Alex, but the code nags at me, demanding my attention. My chest tightens as I try to decide who needs me more right now—my partner or my team.
